title: Unicode ligatures on the web
content:
Hi,

I guess this is the right place to ask about ligature charachtes on the web. What are the main technical issues with using them on the web in a UTF-8 document?

The main issue—that I have found—with ligatures on the web is lack of search engine support. A search engine such as Google does not understand that ‘ [ﬁnd](http://web.archive.org/web/20070825115852/http:/www.google.com/search?client=opera&rls=en&q=%EF%AC%81nd&ie=utf-8&oe=utf-8)’ and ‘ [find](http://web.archive.org/web/20070825115852/http:/www.google.com/search?client=opera&rls=en&q=find&ie=utf-8&oe=utf-8)’ means the same.

 [‹ Making OTF problem](http://web.archive.org/web/20070825115852/http:/www.typophile.com/node/35058 "Go to previous forum topic") [Embedded bitmaps in TTF in Windows ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20070825115852/http:/www.typophile.com/node/34903 "Go to next forum topic")
author: Aleksandersen

comments.content: Sounds like a similar problem with old PS1 typefaces using the ligatures and causing havoc with spell check.

Just so.

Aleks is talking about using hardcoded ligature characters; if browsers and CSS supported simply turning ligatures on via formatting and then handled it at the glyph display level it wouldn’t be a problem.

Regards,

T
Isn’t that what Typophile is doing anyway?
